citation.article-title: Thalassomonas viridans gen. nov., sp. nov., a novel marine gamma-proteobacterium.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Thalassomonas (Tha.las'so.mo.nas. Gr. n. Thalasso the sea; Gr. n. monas a unit; N.L. n. Thalassomonas a monad from the sea)
Gram-negative, strictly aerobic, chemo-organotrophic, halophilic bacteria.
Oxidase- and catalase-positive, motile by single polar flagella.
Cells are rod-shaped and approximately 1.5-2 μm long and 0.8-1 μm wide.
No growth without sea water or the addition of combined marine salts to the medium.
The temperature range for growth is 13-37 °C; no growth at 4 or 40 °C.
Gelatin, casein, starch and lecithin, but not alginate or agar, are hydrolysed.
Nitrate is not reduced to nitrite.
Arginine dihydrolase, lysine decarboxylase, ornithine decarboxylase and indole-production activities are not detected.
The predominant cellular fatty acids are saturated and monounsaturated straight-chain fatty acids.
The DNA G+­C content of the type strain of the type species, CECT 5083T (=XOM25T), is 48.4 mol%.
The genus is affiliated to the γ-Proteobacteria and contains one species, Thalassomonas viridans, which is the type species.
